channel.title: NYT > U.S. > Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Heads to Davos Amid Deep Worries About U.S.-European Alliance
item.description: The gathering of the global elite is set to serve as an all-hands effort to de-escalate tensions between President Trump and America’s allies over his insistence on acquiring Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump leaving the White House on Tuesday night en route to Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Cuban Immigrant Was Killed in ICE Custody, Family Says in Legal Filing
item.description: The family of Geraldo Lunas Campos said a witness saw him choked by guards in an El Paso detention facility this month. Federal officials said he died by suicide.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Camp East Montana, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention facility in El Paso.

item.title: Air Force One Turns Back With Trump After Electrical Issue
item.description: The plane was heading for Switzerland when it turned back for Joint Base Andrews. A White House official said there had been a minor electrical issue.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado, Luke Broadwater, Yan Zhuang and Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Air Force One returned to Joint Base Andrews late Tuesday with President Trump on board after experiencing a “minor electrical issue.”

item.title: House Foreign Affairs Members Call for Machado to Govern Venezuela
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader stressed the need for free elections in her latest bipartisan meeting with lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, meeting with members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

item.title: Pressured by Trump, Mexico Sends 37 Accused Criminals to U.S.
item.description: Mexico has sought to do more to combat its cartels in an effort to stave off airstrikes threatened by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexican police officers at a crime scene in Culiacán, the home territory of the Sinaloa cartel, in 2024.

item.title: ‘God Is Very Proud’: Trump Marks Anniversary With a Victory Lap
item.description: For roughly one hour 45 minutes, President Trump meandered through his accomplishments and grievances, attacked perceived enemies and threatened allies.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump tossed aside a 31-page list of his accomplishments during a briefing at the White House on Tuesday but still had plenty to say about the first year of his second term.

item.title: Trump Calls Renee Good Killing a ‘Tragedy’ and Says ICE Agents Will Make Mistakes
item.description: The change in tone was stark for the president, who said he had been told that Ms. Good’s father was a strong Trump supporter.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: A memorial for Renee Good at the site of her killing.

item.title: DOGE Employees Shared Social Security Data, Court Filing Shows
item.description: Employees detailed to the Social Security Administration shared sensitive data through a nonsecure server, the Justice Department disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Social Security Administration does not know what data was shared on the server, the Justice Department said.

item.title: JD Vance and Second Lady Usha Vance Are Expecting Their 4th Child
item.description: It is the first known time in modern U.S. history that a sitting second lady is expecting a baby while her husband is in office.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and his wife, Usha Vance, at the White House in November.

item.title: Pentagon Hasn’t Yet Been Asked to Plan Greenland Invasion Amid Trump Threats
item.description: Pentagon officials plan for all sorts of military contingencies, but they have not yet been asked to draw up an invasion of Greenland or the aftermath of such an operation.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Nuuk, Greenland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Escalates Tensions With European Allies With Greenland and Gaza Efforts
item.description: President Trump’s bellicose demands about Greenland and participation in his “board of peace” are deepening worries about the fate of the trans-Atlantic alliance.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked how far he was willing to go to acquire Greenland, President Trump told reporters, “You’ll find out.”

item.title: C.I.A.’s New Focus on Latin America Reflected in Raid to Seize Maduro
item.description: A senior U.S. official declined to confirm the specific operations in Venezuela, but said a covert team provided real-time support for the military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s National Guard at the entrance to the country’s largest military complex in Caracas, the capital, after President Nicolás Maduro’s capture on Jan. 3.

item.title: California Republicans Ask Supreme Court to Block New Congressional Map
item.description: Republicans asked the justices to step in after a federal court rejected their claims that the state’s new congressional map violated the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California speaking in Sacramento in November after voters approved an amendment assenting to the new map.

item.title: Some Republicans Begin to Echo Trump’s Case to Acquire Greenland
item.description: While the party remains split as President Trump presses to “take” Greenland, some in his party are publicly embracing his reasoning for wanting to control the territory.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson spoke to the British Parliament in London on Tuesday, implicitly backing President Trump’s argument that Greenland is vital to U.S. national security.

item.title: A Birthday Card Replica From Trump to Epstein Appears on the National Mall
item.description: An oversize card reproduces a suggestive birthday greeting from 2003, released as part of a congressional inquiry. President Trump has denied that he signed it.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: An art installation depicting a replica of a birthday message said to be from President Trump to Jeffrey Epstein appeared on the National Mall overnight on Sunday.

item.title: Macron Vows France Will Not Capitulate to Bullying From Trump
item.description: “We are reaching a time of instability and imbalances,” the French president said in remarks at the World Economic Forum, urging more cooperation among nations.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Comer Rejects Clinton Interview on Epstein, Setting Up Contempt Vote
item.description: The Republican chairman of the Oversight Committee refused an offer to interview the former president under oath, rejecting terms he said were unreasonable.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative James Comer, Republican of Kentucky, at the Capitol last week.

item.title: Prosecutors Subpoena Minnesota Democrats as Part of Federal Inquiry
item.description: The move is a significant expansion of the Justice Department’s investigation into the state’s leaders, including Gov. Tim Walz and Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis at a news conference this month. The Trump administration’s investigation was initially said to have focused on him and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota.

item.title: Trump Threatens New Trade War as Court Weighs Whether to Check Him
item.description: President Trump may be on the verge of having his authority on imposing tariffs curtailed, but that hasn’t slowed down his threats.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president has issued belligerent tariff threats against European countries in recent days.

item.title: One Year In, Searching for a Strategy Behind Trump’s Unpredictability
item.description: One great truth of Trump II so far is that nobody has any idea what tomorrow holds.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:description: The question has only deepened: Is there a strategy behind President Trump's unpredictability — or does it reflect the absence of one?

item.title: Halligan Leaves as U.S. Attorney After Mounting Pressure From Judges
item.description: For weeks, judges have pressed Ms. Halligan to explain why she continues to identify herself in court filings as the U.S. attorney, despite a ruling in November that she was unlawfully appointed to the job.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Judges took the extraordinary step of publicly appealing for applicants to replace Lindsey Halligan, whose short tumultuous tenure was marred by significant missteps in court.

item.title: Greenland’s Leader Says He Cannot Rule Out an American Attack
item.description: Jens-Frederik Nielsen, Greenland’s prime minister, said that an attack on the territory by the United States was “not likely” — but that he could not rule one out.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Sigga Ella for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nuuk, the capital of Greenland. Mute B. Egede, a former prime minister who is now a member of Greenland’s Parliament, said that top officials were reviewing emergency guidance amid threats from President Trump.

item.title: Julia Letlow, Backed by Trump, Enters Louisiana Senate Race to Challenge Bill Cassidy
item.description: Days after President Trump urged her to run, Representative Julia Letlow said she would challenge Mr. Cassidy, a Louisiana Republican who voted to convict Mr. Trump in his second impeachment trial.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call, via AP Images
item.media:description: Representative Julia Letlow of Louisiana entered Congress in 2021 after her husband died from the coronavirus weeks after he won a congressional race in 2020. She ran in a special election.

item.title: Carney’s World Economic Forum Speech Warns of Global Breakdown
item.description: As President Trump continued his quest for Greenland, Prime Minister Mark Carney said great powers were unrestrained and urged medium-size countries to band together.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada speaking in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Bessent Attended a Supreme Court Argument. Now He’s Telling Powell Not To.
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said it was a mistake for Jerome Powell to attend arguments in a case on Fed independence. But Mr. Bessent attended a tariff case.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: “If you’re trying not to politicize the Fed, for the Fed chair to be sitting there trying to put his thumb on the scale is a real mistake,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said.

item.title: Trump Calls U.K. Deal on Indian Ocean Islands ‘Great Stupidity,’ in Blow to Starmer
item.description: President Trump’s criticism reversed his administration’s previous support for the deal, in which Britain relinquished control of the Chagos Islands, site of a joint U.S.-British base.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Diego Garcia, the largest island in the Chagos Archipelago, is the site of a major military base used by Britain and the United States.

item.title: With Threats to Greenland, Trump Sets America on the Road to Conquest
item.description: After a century of defending other countries against foreign aggression, the United States is now positioned as an imperial power trying to seize another nation’s land.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump has declared that the only limits on his global power are “my own morality” and “my own mind.”

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Misleading Claims After One Year Back in Office
item.description: The president has justified many significant moves of his second term with inaccurate claims and overstated boasts.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu and McKinnon de Kuyper
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s First Year Could Have Lasting Economic Consequences
item.description: President Trump’s policies have so far done little to change the overall state of the American economy, but economists warn they will ultimately weaken the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Economists from across the ideological spectrum warn that President Trump is setting the country on a path that will, in the long run, leave the economy less dynamic in the decades ahead.

item.title: Majority of Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Hawaii Gun Law
item.description: The court grappled with a Hawaii law restricting carrying concealed weapons onto private property, setting up a potential clash between gun and property rights.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.category: New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v Bruen (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atom Kasprzycki, left, and Jason Wolford are part of a group of Hawaii gun owners challenging the law, which requires gun owners to get the explicit consent of a property owner before carrying a concealed weapon.

item.title: How Trump Flexes Power in White House Meetings With Zelensky and Others
item.description: With cameras rolling, President Trump met with more than 40 international leaders in his first year back in office.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

item.title: President Trump’s Chosen Artist? A Christian Speed Painter.
item.description: Vanessa Horabuena has painted presidential portraits and Jesus for Mr. Trump, and this month, he sold one of her paintings for $2.75 million in a charity auction.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vanessa Horabuena, whom President Trump has called “one of the greatest artists anywhere in the world.”

item.title: Trump Threatens 200% Tariffs on Wine if France Declines to Join Gaza Board of Peace
item.description: France has said it will not join President Trump’s “Board for Peace.” Its agriculture minister described his tariff threat as “blackmail.”
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Violette Franchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump threatened on Monday to impose 200 percent tariffs on French wine.
